importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the signing of the Paris Climate Agreement, which fundamentally changed the trajectory of global warming and is central to the study's comparison of climate outcomes before and after the agreement.
The study refers to the period from 1991 to 2020 as a baseline for defining 'comparable days,' which enables the attribution of temperature increases to climate change.
This is the publication date of the study, making it the most current scientific assessment of climate-related superhot days and their global distribution.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects future increases in superhot days up to 2100, illustrating long-term climate risks and the ongoing impact of current emissions policies.
The period from 2015 to 2025 represents the era of post-Paris Agreement climate action, during which the world has already added 11 superhot days annually.

keyTakeAways: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central shows that climate change will add 57 superhot days annually by 2100 under current commitments, half the worst-case scenario of 114 days.
The Paris Climate Agreement in 2015 reduced the projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, significantly lowering but not eliminating the risk of dangerous heat exposure.

The increase in superhot days is highly unequal: small island nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face far more additional heat days than major polluters like the U.S., China, and India.
Panama is projected to experience 149 extra superhot days annually — a stark contrast to the U.S., China, and India, which face only 23–30 extra days despite contributing 42% of global CO₂ emissions.
The disproportionate heat impact reveals deep climate injustice, potentially fueling geopolitical tensions between high-emission and vulnerable nations.
Experts warn that even under current policies, tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by dangerous heat, with thousands dying in heatwaves annually.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current commitments to the Paris Climate Agreement, the planet will add 57 superhot days annually by 2100 — nearly two months of dangerous heat. This is half the increase from the pre-Paris worst-case scenario of 114 days. The study reveals a stark global inequality in heat exposure: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive spikes in superhot days — with Panama projected at 149 extra days — while major emitters such as the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 additional days despite contributing 42% of global CO₂ emissions. Experts warn that tens of thousands or millions of people will be affected by the rising heat, with thousands dying in heatwaves each year. The findings highlight deep climate injustice and potential geopolitical instability between high-emission and vulnerable nations.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
